The pink packet has a long, tangled and not always sweet history.

It's called Sweet 'N Low.
Rich Cohen joins us from our New York bureau.
Hello there.
Hi.

I don't think its sour grapes.

A lot of these stories are the kind of stories you might just tell around the table when you're in the club.

And to me it's sort of like the greatest story I know.

You know, in that here was the problem.
The problem was the bitter aftertaste.

Well, he was a counterman.

Why won't this pour?

Packet sugar.

And he had this idea, working with a guy at a pharmaceutical company, of making fake sugar, which believe it or not did not exist.

Splenda.

Why is that?

Uh-huh.
My Aunt Gladys did not leave her room from the Nixon administration until shortly after the attacks of September 11th, when Betty died, Grandma Betty died, her mother died.
She took to her bed for various reasons sometime in the mid '70s and pretty much stayed in her room her entire adult life.
And she came out of her room to attend the funeral of my grandma Betty, her second parent.
I always felt in some way that she's the key to the whole story, that there was a sort of a Citizen Kane-like quality to the story, and that Aunt Gladys was the key to unlocking it.
And Aunt Gladys in some way was guarding her parents.
She was guarding access to her parent's love.
And in some way all the kids were fighting for the blessing of the parents.
And Gladys was like in the desert sitting next to the well.
And the well contained the love of the parents.

She, at the end of my grandma's life, it was my grandmother and Gladys alone in their house, still in the same house where my mother grew up in Flatbush, with Gladys taking care of Betty and actually drawing a salary for taking care of her.
And it was in this moment that the will was changed, not by my Grandpa Ben, but my Grandma Betty.
While she was in the house being cared for by, by her daughter, Gladys, the will was changed.
And the sentence was added, To Ellen, my mother, and her issue, me, my brother and sister, I leave nothing for reasons I deem sufficient.
What do you think your grandmother Betty meant when she said reasons I deem sufficient?
I don't know.
It's like the mystery of the book that I'm trying to puzzle out.
And you know, there's a lot of reasons given.
One is that my mother suggested a doctor to operate on my grandfather who needed heart surgery.

But that's so crazy that I felt there were a lot of things.
I felt my mother and my grandfather Ben had a very close relationship.
And this actually threatened my Grandma Betty.
And felt that if Ben loved his daughter too much he couldn't love her.
I mean I felt it was really intense and it was Brooklyn and it was this hothouse world.
But the thing that makes it so amazing, of course, is its connection to the product, and the fact that it's all sort of like I'd like to imagine it.
You'd tear open a Sweet 'N Low packet and pour it out and all these people pour out into your coffee.
That's what you should know when you're using it next time.
Going around and talking about the book I find that there's - this is a lot, this happens to a lot of people.
I mean, these family fortunes rip apart families.
And basically you get generations of people that don't work.
And generations of people that try to protect their money.
And other generations of people that have been kicked out.
And they're all fighting for the same legacy.
It goes back to the Bible, really.

That's what I think now.
It's basically how the country was built.
